text: THE PHONE RINGS, and THE GUARD CAPTAIN answers in French:
<Hallo? No we haven’t opened yet.> (listens) <From Las Vegas? In America? That’s ridiculous...> (listens again) <Of course. I understand. Right away. ..>

TWO GUARDS hurry down the hallway toward the VAULT DOOR. put in dual keys, press a code, and wait a moment -- Then door swings open EXPELLING A TREMENDOUS GUST OF GASEOUS FUMES, causing the guards to cough and gag, and we MATCH CUT TO
A ROLLS-ROYCE PHANTOM bursts through the SMOKE rising fro underground heating vent. It rolls out of the parking exi and turns onto the strip, mixing in with the heavy Vegas traffic.
Michael Atlas dabs at his forehead with a handkerchief; Roderigo sits beside him, facing Alex and London. Tension in the air. A silent beat, then:
Did you check out that mad honey in the third row? Aisle seat? The shizzle. She was giving me the eye the whole show, too.
Which explains why you were late on half your cues. Don’t let it happen next time.
Easy, tiger. Didn’t you see that audience? We killed tonight.

Not quite. Everyone was slow on their cues. Like doing a show with the cast of Dawn of the Dead- and not that new fast-zombie remake crap, either. I’m talking classic slow-ass shambling old-school zombie shit. Lights were a disaster. Were we all in the same theater? A moment of tense silence between the four men, then:
Still, we pulled it off, didn’t we? Michael allows himself to nod, then smile slightly, easin the tension. He looks down at his watch:
Nine a.m. in Paris. QUICK CUT TO THE VAULT IN THE PARISIAN BANK: THE GUARDS r in, waving away the fumes, and see that whatever money wa there is GONE.
Michael Atlas leans back, finally allowing himself to rel MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) Tomorrow’s gonna be an interesting day.
The flat desert landscape stretches away beyond the row o townhouses lining the street. The wind blows. A TOYOTA CAMRY is parked outside a modest house, engine running...

DYLAN HOBBES, mid-thirties, eyes more tired than his year would suggest, looks out at THE FRONT WINDOW OF THE HOUSE: behind which a WOMAN is visible moving around the kitchen, serving breakfast to a downcast looking LITTLE GIRL.  10. Dylan takes in the tableau for a moment, face tensing wit self-recrimination.
Damn. He reaches for the car door, and we cut to:

head_text.subj: THE FRONT DOOR OF THE HOUSE SWINGING OPEN

text: To reveal CATHERINE HOBBES, glaring at Dylan furiously.
You were supposed to be here at seven o’clock. Last night.
I’m sorry Catherine. Something came up at work, and...

And you call last minute, so I can’t make any contingency plans, and I miss my meeting with practically the only clients I have left? (almost exploding) You’re not taking her for the weekend. You don’t deserve her.

It was an emergency, damnit. I don’t work delivering goddamn pizza! If something happens I... Then Dylan catches himself, seeing the LITTLE GIRL sittin the table beyond Catherine; her eyes are on her plate, tr to ignore her parents’ fight. DYLAN (CONT’D) You’re not keeping me from my daughter.
Dylan steps into the sunny space and sits down across fro his morose daughter, whose name is HANNA. He smiles tight
Hey, baby. Sorry I couldn’t make it last night. But I got us all hooked up for the weekend, and-  ll.
You’re never getting back together with Mom, are you? Dylan is silent, caught off guard. HANNA (CONT’D) What did you do to make her so mad at you?

It’s not what I did. It’s what I didn’t do. Hanna gives no evidence of understanding that. DYLAN (CONT’D) It’s like school. You know how you have responsibilities? Get to class on time, do your homework, talk nice to your teachers... You don’t do those things, you get expelled.
Mom threw you out because you didn’t do your homework?

Something like that. But I think this weekend I’m going to earn a little extra credit. (smiles) We’re going to go to that new water- park, out on 66. Then... Then DYLAN’S CEL-PHONE BUZZES. Despite looks from both Hannah and Catherine, who is now in the kitchen doorway, Dylan looks down at the number -- His shoulders slump, an looks back up at his daughter: DYLAN (CONT’D) It’s an emergency. When it’s over, I’ll make it up to you... That’s a promise.

FBI AGENTS are seated around the room. The last to enter Dylan Hobbes -- still wearing the frustration of his morn on his face. TITLE: FBI Headquarters - Nevada Field Office  12. The air is filled with early morning banter. Standing in front of a MONITOR is SAC LOUIS HERNANDEZ.

Nice of you to join us, Agent Hobbes. Alright, ladies, now that our star player is here, let’s cut the chatter- we got work to do. (the room quiets down) Got one for the X-Files, people. Our office in Paris called last night. There was a bank robbery there that took place about 7:30 a.m., Paris time. Approximately one and a half million euros disappeared out of the vault of Rue Rivoli branch of the Credit Lyonnais. The reason we are talking about it here, is this video taken from the vault. THE IMAGE OF MICHAEL ATLAS and the MAN FROM PARIS comes u the screen. HERNANDEZ (CONT’D) This is world famous magician Michael Atlas. The man with him is, as far as we know, a member of the audience from his show. When this image was captured, Atlas was on stage with the Four Horsemen, in the middle of their act at the MGM Grand. AGENT FULLER, a big bear of a man, mumbles from the back:
You’re saying these guys robbed a Paris bank -- from Vegas?
I’m saying that’s what it looks like. ON THE MONITOR the audience in the theatre leap and scram for the MONEY fluttering down from above:
Was it real?
Was what real?  13.
The money. Falling from the ceiling. Was it real or funny money?
From the little we were able to recover- real as a heart attack.
So they pull this thing off, and don’t even keep the score? Who are these guys?
More pertinently- where are they?
They’re staying in the Excelsior Hotel. Got the entire top floor rented out. We called, and they’re there. So they don’t appear to be particularly worried about all this. Another AGENT stands:
Well, what are we waiting for?

For Inspector Alma Vargas, of the Las Vegas Special Investigation Unit, to brief us so we know exactly what we’re dealing with. She’ll be liaising with us on this case. Inspector..? ALMA VARGAS, a beautiful young detective with a caustic attitude stands, aware of the instant attention she comma from all the men in the room; not necessarily for the thi she wants to be noticed for. She’s used to it. Alma press a remote, and an image of THE FOUR HORSEMEN appears on th

The Four Horsemen are like a magic superhero team. Each one of them was an established magician in his own right before they joined forces, for what they’re billing as three special shows over the span of ten days. (MORE)
Last night being the first. Friday they’re in Atlantic City, Wednesday next, in Los Angeles...
-Wow. You read the brochure. How did you manage to do all this “research,” Inspector?

Police officers in Vegas are used to working late hours. Unlike FBI agents, apparently. Alma weathers the chorus of boos and jeers that greet her enjoying it, then continues: ALMA VARGAS (CONT’D) I’m not done yet. Allow me to drop a little more wisdom on you. We’ll start with Santayana... A MONTAGE of IMAGES BEGINS as she talks; starting on a SM LATINO BOY wandering wide eyed through a small town trave carnival: ALMA VARGAS (V.O.) (CONT’D) Roderigo Santayana was born in Culiacan, Mexico. Ran away from home to join a traveling show, just dike in the stories... IMAGES OF RODERIGO, various ages, working on all kind of MAGICAL DEVICES; robot fortune tellers, clockwork contraptions, floating crystal balls, coffins with secret compartments, etc. ALMA VARGAS (V.O.) (CONT’D) He's apparently a genius at designing mechanical devices and illusions. Got his own show on Telemundo a few years back... RODERIGO floats over an awed studio audience. ALMA VARGAS (V.O.) (CONT’D) His special, “Ole Roderigo”, was highest rated broadcast behind the Mexico vs. Brazil soccer game. Guy moves to LA, gets himself a William Morris agent... RODERIGO holds court at the VIP table surrounded by silic filled groupies.  15. ALMA VARGAS (V.0.) (CONT’D) Spends his money on coke and strip clubs. He's considered a disgrace in the magic community, but the boys all wish they were him. Next, we have Alex Hero... IMAGE OF ALEX as a young boy in a baseball uniform, repeatedly throwing a ball into his own glove: ALMA VARGAS (V.O.) (CONT’D) Real name, Alexander Hess. All American boy. Little League all star. Only this boy could care less about baseball. What he’s into is magic. Sleight of hand, to be specific... Alex throws the ball into the glove again; then smiles an opens the glove-_the ball has disappeared. We widen out t see ALEX IS ON STAGE in a television studio: a neon logo behind him reads “AMERICA’S GOT SKILLZ.” ALMA VARGAS (V.0.) (CONT’D) Wins a talent competition on the tube and becomes an overnight sensation. He immediately gets emancipated from his family and moves to Vegas, where he hooks up with the Horsemen. The third member of which is a Brit actually named London... LONDON OSBORNE reaches a hand out toward the camera, his gleaming with intensity. ALMA VARGAS (V.O. (CONT’D) London Osborne. He's a mentalist, hypnotist. Messes with your head, basically. Jedi mind-tricks. Supposed to be the best there ever WAS +. IMAGES of people lying like planks across two chairs whil others jump up and down on their stomachs, an OLD WOMAN impossibly holding a huge FAT MAN over her head, etc. ALMA VARGAS (V.0.) (CONT’D) Performed on the West End for years. Repeat command performances for the Queen. But it all went to hell one night...  London is at a posh club, DRUNKEN CLUBBER pushes through, splashes a drink in his face.

If you’re so bloody smart, why didn’t you see that coming? Aren’t you the great mentalist? Seventy pounds a seat- You’re not worth the piss I just took in the back bloody alley, mate. London looks icy calm:

Excuse me gentlemen, ladies... (turns to the clubber) So you want your money’s worth? IMAGE OF THE CLUBBER in an emergency room, with glass sticking out of his mouth, as the doctors remove it without killing him.

Weird thing is, no one there could remember if Osborne did it, or the guy did to himself. In any case, Osborne served three years for aggravated assault. It’s toward the end of that time that the Four Horsemen came together... 16. surrounded by an adoring crowd. A stands in front of London and his broken struggle to LONDON sits in front the protective glass in a PRISON VISITING ROOM.
What are you doing this side of the pond? REVERSE SHOWS MICHAEL ATLAS on the other side of the glas
Came here to make you an offer.
If you think I’m gonna hold your bloody tails for you or do filler bits you can sod off. I’m my own man.  17.
I’m not asking you to do filler, and I don’t wear tails, bloody or otherwise. I’m putting together a group- a super-group, if you will.
Like Asia, or something? Remember that song, how did it go..? Was shite, really.
More like Cream, or Led Zeppelin, or the Dream Team. Three shows, that’11l open up a new life for you, with more fame and fortune than you can imagine.
I have a pretty big imagination.
(smiles) Mine’s bigger.
What about this Michael Atlas guy?
Alma turns to SAC HERNANDEZ:

Not much. Born Menachem Joachim Murphy in the Bronx. Work out the genetics yourselves. First came on the radar as a street performer in New York. Youtube videos of his performances had over twenty million hits. He was recently made several offers to headline his own show in Vegas, but formed the Four Horsemen instead. (pauses) And there you have it.
Thank you, officer Vargas. Good work. Now...
Yeah, wow, none of us know how to access Wikipedia. (MORE)
Thank you so much. (looks up from his I-

In the meantime, while you were regaling us with that informative yet banal information, I tracked down the credit card number of the guy from the audience who was in the vault with Atlas... Remember him? His name is Etienne Glickman, and he used the same card to rent a room at the Hard Rock for six nights. Tonight being his last. (smiles) Think it might be a good idea to talk to him before he splits town?
A phalanx of UNMARKED POLICE cars pull into the driveway, POLICE OFFICERS and FBI AGENTS fling the doors open and r out...
Dylan Hobbes sits in the driver’s seat, Detective Alma Va beside him, Agent Fuller in the back. Alma starts to get out, sees neither Dylan or Fuller is moving:
Aren’t you coming?
What for? Got an army going in there to pick up a little French dude.
You don’t want a piece of the collar?

We got a saying here in the bureau, inspector. Collars are for do... (stops himself) Not an applicable saying in this instance. Anyway, cops make collars, we solve cases. Knock yourself out, though. Alma gives Dylan a disgusted look, then gets out of the c and heads toward the hotel entrance. Dylan watches her ba admiringly, as:  19.
Collars are for dogs? Did you actually say that?
I caught myself.
Like that shit you followed up with was any better?
She’s into me.

A CADILLAC SEVILLE pulls into a driveway, and THADDEUS BRADLEY- the acerbic older man we last saw at the magic s gets out of the car. He sees the arm on his mailbox is up so he reaches for the latch, then FIREWORKS EXPLODE OUT OF THE MAILBOX with a BANG, causing to jump backward. RECORDED LAUGHTER comes from within the Mailbox, like the laughter at the end of Michael Jackson’ “Thriller.” Thaddeus sighs. Clearly this kind of thing happens to him often... INT. LIVING ROOM - THADDEUS’S VILLA - LATER Thaddeus at the bar, mixing himself a MARTINI, while in f the TELEVISION IS ON; we hear the NEWS-REPORT:

-- Authorities are responding to reports that the French bank purportedly robbed during the Four Horsemen's performance at the MGM grand was in fact, actually robbed... Thaddeus steps into the room, sipping his drink. The plac is a shrine to himself, posters and pictures of him everywhere; most prominent being a FOX TV SHOW poster of Thaddeus standing beneath a logo that reads: “MAGIC’S GREATEST SECRETS EXPOSED.” NEWSCASTER (T.V.) (CONT’D) -- Which, if true, has many experts saying is the most daring feat of magic since the heyday of Harry Houdini himself...  20. ON THE TV we see images the FOUR HORSEMEN exiting their h surrounded by a phalanx of COPS, FBI AGENTS, and NEWS-MED NEWSCASTER (T.V.) (CONT’D) -- The media firestorm has made the Horsemen, at least for today, the most famous act in show business... CLOSE ON THADDEUS: his features tightening with agitation he watches the tube: NEWSCASTER (T.V.) (CONT’D) -- The question on everyone’s mind, now: are they going to enjoy their fame as free men, or behind bars..? cur TO:

Each one showing a separate INTERROGATION ROOM in which o of the Four Horsemen is being held; The images turn from to red, measuring temperature... Blood pressure... Pulse. There are all kinds of fluctuations happening on the scre for ROOM #1, where young ALEX HERO, hands cuffed, is bein shoved into a seat by AGENT FULLER:
Yo, Pooh Bear, why you got to be like that? None of the others got cuffed and shit...
Agent Fuller steps away from Alex, watched by Dylan and A

That’s cause none of the others called me cute nicknames, Vanilla Ice. Besides, you’re supposed to be the sleight of hand artist, aren’t you..? (grins) So why don’t you work your way out of those cuffs yourself? Be a nice trick.
I’m not giving you any excuses to mess my ass up.  21.
Agent Hobbes and detective Vargas are right here; no one’s gonna do anything to you. You want those off, do it yourself. Alex takes a moment, then:
Okay. But I’d like to give them back to you. Would you put your hands on the table for me, please? Agent Fuller takes a beat, then he leans over and puts hi hands on the table.

This better be... Alex snatches Agent Fuller’s hands, then slams them back on the table in a single dizzyingly quick motion, and Dylan and Alma reflexively step forward, then stop as the see that Agent Fuller is now wearing the handcuffs on his own wris Agent Fuller glares at Alex; then reaches his cuffed hand his pocket, fishing around in there, but:
Lost something? Kind of sloppy for an FBI agent, aren’t you, Pooh Bear? (turns to Alma) You started on that soda yet, miss..?
Vargas. Detective Vargas, to you. (raises the unopened CAN OF DIET COKE in her hand) Nope.

Feels a little heavy for a diet beverage, doesn’t it? Alma’s eyes narrow. She shakes the diet coke can- there i clinking sound from inside it. She peels the cap off, the walks over to the table and turns it over, letting the so spill onto the interrogation table, until a SINGLE KEY dr out of the hole and clinks onto the table top.  22. ALEX (CONT’D) Hookers do tricks. Next time you want to see magic, buy a ticket to the show. The three law enforcement officers look at Alex with newf respect in their eyes. He’s young, but clearly a formidab opponent.
Don’t plan on leaving town any time soon, Mr. Hero.
Roderigo Santayana shakes his head:

-- Of course we’re going to leave town. We have a show in Atlantic City Friday night. If we had reason to run we would have already been gone, no? On what grounds do think you can keep us here? Dylan and Vargas sit in front of Roderigo, Agent Fuller i the b.g.
You know very well on what grounds. This is some serious shit you’re in Mr. Santayana. You’re not on stage anymore.

No? Then what is this little “interrogation room” of yours? Lights, gadgets. Lie detectors, heat sensors. You even have a two- way mirror. A room that conveys a sense of privacy, yet there’s at least a dozen people listening to our every word. You put on your shows, too, Mr. FBI, I’1l put on mine.
You crossed the line into my show when you robbed a bank-
In Paris? While we were in Las Vegas?  23. Alma Vargas is holding another can of diet coke. She shak it, hears nothing, so she peels off the cap and takes a s
Just ‘cause you were in Vegas doesn’t mean you didn’t have confederates over there in Paris while-
Confederates? You have the bank video. You saw what everyone else saw.
Which was Michael Atlas and a member- purported- member of your audience, in the vault. In Paris.
Which is impossible, of course. (smiles) You think I built a transporter, like in a science fiction movie? I’m good, but no one is that good.
Right, Mr. Santayana. Which is why we’re here. And why we’re gonna stay here, until you give us an explanation. Roderigo takes a moment, then shrugs his shoulders:
Coincidence?
Dylan is looking a little more pissed off now, as he snap
-- That’s your story, after the shit you pulled? Coincidence? London Osborne is sitting across table from Dylan and Alm Vargas. His dark eyes burn, his temper always in check.
Good a story as any, oi? Has the benefit of being the truth, as well.  24.
And you expect me to buy that?
Yes.
That’s it? The whole great mentalist shtick- Just look someone in the eye and lie to them? You expect that bullshit to work on me?
Why not? You expect it to work on your wife, don’t you? Dylan freezes. The tension in the air is suddenly palpabl LONDON (CONT’D) What’s her name?
I’m not telling you my wife’s name.

Not your wife. The name of the bird you were out with the other night, when you told your wife you were working late so you couldn’t make it on time to pick up your own kid -- What was her name? (eyes gleaming) Or don’t you even remember it? There’ve been so many, haven’t... Dylan snaps across the table, grabbing London by the coll London just stares into Dylan’s eyes, not moving a muscle and Dylan relents, stepping back, aware of the eyes of Alma a Agent Fuller on him. London sits back down in his chair. LONDON (CONT’D) Coincidence. I’d leave it at that, if I were you. But because I know you won’t, I’1l simply remind you-
Michael Atlas sits comfortably in his chair, in his t-shi and jeans:  25.

-- My lawyers are better than your lawyers. Better paid, better dressed and better prepared. Which is what it’s all about, isn’t it? Preparation. We’re prepared. You’re not. Which is why, despite your tiresome threats to the contrary, we are going to walk out of here free of charges. Dylan, Alma and Agent Fuller glare at Michael. All lookin they’ve had it up to here with these guys.
You are one cocky son of a bitch, aren’t you? In fact you are a quartet of cocky sons of bitches.
That’s why we get paid the big bucks.
So what did you need the money for? Why risk everything on a stunt like this?
You seem to be forgetting we don’t have the money.

Not all of it. But hardly any of the cash that fell on that audience in your little Robin Hood bit was recovered. You could have kept the lion’s share for yourselves, for all we know. Michael turns his eyes on Alma, studies her carefully.

It’s clear, detective Vargas, that all you know does not amount to very much. There’s no way to tie the money we- donated- with the money from the bank. Unless you can put me in that vault, you’ve got nothing.
We have Etienne Glickman.  26. Michael raises his eyebrows, as if to ask- "Who?” ALMA VARGAS (CONT’D) The “audience member” you brought up onto the stage. Your plant.

Plant? The little French guy? You don’t know the first thing about magic, do you? What good could he possibly have been to me as plant? (smiles) Obviously you haven’t questioned him yet. I wish I could be there for that one. I haven’t had a good laugh in a while.
You should check out Jerry at the Sands. It’s a goddam laugh riot.

So I’ve heard. But I’ma compulsive workaholic. It’s a failing of mine. So unless you have a better hand than the one you’ve been showing, I’d like to get out of here and start rehearsals for our next show.

Dylan, Alma, Agent Fuller and several others are sitting around, surrounded by empty fast food containers, looking beat. A RE-RUN of Michael Atlas’s interrogation is playin on a monitor. One of the agents groans:
I can’t watch this again. What a prick.
They were all pricks. Like they were trying to piss us off on purpose.
Nothing like rock stars, though. Remember when we had to bring in U2? Now those guys took it toa whole other level of prickness.  27.
Prickishness.
What?
You said “prickness.” That’s not a word. The word is “prickishness.”
Whoa. Sorry to have blundered into your area of expertise. ON THE MONITOR: Michael Atlas grins and says:
-- You don’t know the first thing about magic, do you?
He’s right, of course. You people really don’t know the first thing about magic... Every head in the room turns, to see
Standing in the doorway of the operations room:
-- But I do. I trust you’1ll excuse me for letting myself in unannounced.
Who the hell are you?
Thaddeus Bradley. Probably the most hated magician on the planet.
My reputation precedes me. Still, “Hate” might be too strong a word.
Actually, considering how many sneaky, vindictive weirdos do hate you, I’m amazed you’re still alive.  28.
Am I missing something here? You know this guy?

Only from T.V. -- And Wikipedia. (turns to Dylan) I work entertainment in Las Vegas, agent Hobbes. It’s my job to know who’s who in town, so that when something like this goes down, not everyone is playing catch up. (then) -Even if it is at the expense of a less exciting social life. Agent Fuller winces for Dylan, as Alma rises and walks to coffee machine. ALMA VARGAS (CONT’D) Thaddeus Bradley has been exposing other magicians’ secrets for years. Embarrassed them, really. Wickname is the career killer. He even had a low rated Fox Show for short spell, where he...
The ratings were fine. The network simply didn’t know where to place it. Not to mention my books, two of which sat on the New York Times non-fiction best seller list for months.
Whatever. What I want to know is- what the hell are you doing here?

Isn’t it obvious? (then) I’ve seen countless people try to figure out the mechanisms of countless tricks -- Your faces are not exactly flushed with the thrill of success. Dylan shakes off his anger at Alma’s jibe, and faces Thaddeus.
We’ll figure it out.  29.
It’ll take time. Time you don’t have. The clock is on. Three shows in ten days- what you saw was merely the warm up act.
And you know this because-?
I know show business. The magic business, in particular. And because I know Michael Atlas. (pauses) He was my student. Perhaps my brightest. But everything he knows, he learned from me.
And what’s in this for you?

Isn’t that obvious, as well? (no answer) Relevance. (gathers himself) I want my name mentioned in every press conference you give about this case; and when it’s solved, and the Four Horsemen are behind bars, I want to be given the credit for breaking it. That’s what’s in it for me.
The FBI doesn’t work with circus freaks.
When in Rome...

I’ll run it by brass. Leave your information and we’ll contact you. But before you do that, given the day I’ve had, I want you to know one thing... (pauses) If you point your finger at my pocket, and I reach in there and find your card, I swear on my mother I will shoot you where you stand.  30.
A LEAR JET THUNDERS OVERHEAD -- Touching down on the tarm and we cut to: THE FOUR HORSEMEN exiting their private jet, luggage in h They walk toward a BLACK LIMOUSINE waiting for them nearb
THE LIMOUSINE glides toward the lights of ATLANTIC CITY glittering in the near distance; we hear on the SOUNDTRAC
-- Let’s cut to the chase: I know you're never gonna tell us how you did it, or even if you did it...

The FOUR HORSEMEN are seated around an interview table, facing the excitable young D.J., who continues: RADIO D.J. -- So the question I have to ask you is- Are you gonna do it again? London Osborne leans toward his mic and smiles:
Come see our show Friday night and find out.
Word. I’11 be doing my song, too, from my new album- “Alex Hero steals your Heart”- so bum rush it, ladies.

head_text.subj: IMAGES, AS THE INTERVIEW CONTINUES ON

text: SOUNDTRACK -- Dozens of RADIO STATION PHONE OPERATORS tak CALLS, typing in names and addresses into their computers
The tickets to this show are being picked by random lottery, and are completely free, isn’t that right?

That's right. Gift to our fans, from the Horsemen and our sponsors, the good people at Stonebridge Life.  31. LOTTERY BALLS WITH NAMES ON THEM FLY around inside an AIR CHAMBER, on a local MORNING SHOW -- Alex Hero reaches in snatches out ball after ball, watched by the show’s HOSTS

We have two hundred seats available for our listeners right here, so call in if you want to see this incredible -- event. I’m not sure you can even call it just a “magic show” anymore... A COMPUTER IMAGE OF A THEATER SEATING PLAN fills the scre as SEAT AFTER SEAT IS FILLED UP, turning from blue to red RADIO D.J. (V.0.) (CONT’D) Some call you illusionists, some call you magicians; now some are calling you criminals. What do you have to say about that? THE COMPUTER IMAGE DISSOLVES into a HIGH ANGLE of the ACT AUDITORIUM, filled with empty red seats -- A LONE FIGURE steps onto the dark stage, becoming recognizable as MICHA ATLAS.

A man was nailed to a cross once. Killed in broad daylight by the powers that be. He was laid to rest inside of a dark cave, and the entrance was covered over with a rock. Three days later, he was gone... DOLLY IN ON MICHAEL as he takes in the dark theater:
It took Jesus three days to get out of an escape proof vault, and they said he was the son of God. I can do it three minutes -- So what does that make me?
CAMERA MOVES TOWARD an upper floor WINDOW, as we hear DYL
Son of a bitch...  32. INT. SECTION CHIEF’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Dylan, Alma Vargas, and Agent Fuller are standing in fron SAC Hernandez; Dylan fumes:
-- I’ve never seen a guiltier bunch of perps in my life, and we let them fly off to Atlantic city just like that.

Then make the case. Right now all they’re guily of is being a bunch of cocky bastards. (angry) They don’t have to prove they didn’t do it. We have to prove they did. Our job is harder, and it pays less. Way of the world. (then) What about their staff? Stagehands? Employees?
We have whatever personnel we can spare on it, but-

Cogs in a machine. The Horsemen employ dozens of people at any given show; each person seems to know just enough to allow them to do their job. Maybe somebody’s wise to something, but I doubt it. And magic people are a tight lipped bunch, as it is. I doubt we’ll get far. Certainly not in three days.
So that’s it? That’s all you got?
We still got the French guy.
Not for long. Got a call from the State Department. Either you pin something on him that can stick, or he’s on tonight’s flight back to the land of frog legs and cheese.  33.
ETIENNE GLICKMAN, exhausted and irate, is sitting opposit the table from Alma, who is alone in the room with him.

I told you once, I told you twice, I’1l tell you an ‘undred times: I was in the theater, here in Las Vegas, yes? They call me to the stage, they wrap me in a fabric, and suddenly I am in a small room with a nice couch, where I am served coffee and cakes by a pretty girl. Not as pretty as you, but pretty enough-
I’m sure she was. Go on, Mr. Glickman.

(Tressler is now glaring at Michael in open fury) Ladies and gentlemen, our sponsor knows a little bit about magic as well. You see, Arthur Tressler likes to buy insurance companies at discounted prices, and then make their assets disappear. Well, they don’t really disappear: he takes those assets which are to be kept safe for payouts to his customers, and deposits them into his own accounts. And they call us crooks. London erases 800,000 from Tressler’s account on the boar then flips the board around, and shows that GLORIA’S ACCO is now showing $800,019.50. The crowd laughs; but: MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) I know... it’s just numbers on a blackboard. Mr. Tressler, would you care to check your bank balance? Tressler takes out his CELL-PHONE, presses a few numbers the screen; and suddenly  58. SCREENS ALL AROUND THE STAGE COME TO LIFE; replicating th IMAGE OF TRESSLER’S CELL-PHONE SCREEN. His account shows 258,000,045 -- Eight hundred thousand dollars are missing
This better be a joke, Atlas.

Or what? You’ll call the cops? They’re already here, remember? I’m sure they’1ll have plenty of questions for you on the way out. But before that... (to the audience) Everyone’s heard about all the money raining down at our last show- Due to circumstances beyond our control, that won’t be happening tonight. THE CROWD BOOS LOUDLY; Michael raises his hands: MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) But cash is so old school, don’t you think? Never let it be said the Four Horsemen don’t move with the times. (smiles) How many of you have these new- fangled phones with high speed internet and whatnot? A scattering of HANDS GO UP. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) Allow me to bring the rest of you into the 21st Century. Would you all check you pockets... your hand- bags? ANGLES ON THE AUDIENCE: all finding NEW PHONES nestled in their pockets and personal belongings. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) The X-Phone, made by Nakano- our new sponsor- which we’re gonna need, considering what’s about to happen to our old one. Now, if you turn those on, you’ll find all your information has been transferred to your new phones. Addresses, phone numbers and everything.  59.
As the phones are turned on, the darkness illuminated by blue screens like the sky being filled with a thousand st

Tonight's audience was supposed to be chosen by a random drawing. But I have to admit, we cheated. Everyone here has one thing in common -- You're all customers of companies Arthur Tressler has purchased. You believed yourselves to be in good hands- but if you need a large payout there will be nothing in the bank.... ANGLES ON THE AUDIENCE: Distraught faces lit blue by the phones. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) He’s been hustling you like a street-corner shell-game artist. When audited he moves the money from one account to another. He has robbed each and every one of you. (pauses) But fear not. Tonight this theater is a true house of magic... ANGLE ON DYLAN AND ALMA: looking around themselves, as th air is filled with glittering confetti that rises from th floor upwards -- the entire space filling with pixie dust MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) Let it surround you. And now access your accounts, and check your brand new bank balances.
FILLING UP WITH LARGE NUMBERS -- WHILE THE SCREEN that ho TRESSLER’S ACCOUNT shows his number STEADILY DIMINISHING, cur TO:

head_text.subj: ARTHUR TRESSLER HIDING HIS FACE FROM A HUNDRED CAMERA FLA

text: As he tries to get to his limo in the parking lot behind theater; being shouted from all directions... THE CAMERA BOOMS UP on the hectic scene, as Tressler is swallowed up the mass of cameras, reporters and surging onlookers; on

-- In a theatrical twist, Arthur Tressler, president of Stonebridge Life Insurance, was exposed as a criminal by the Four Horsemen, whose show was sponsored by his own company..+.+ TELEVISED IMAGE SHOWS A HUGE CROWD shouting at Tressler a holding up “FOUR HORSEMEN” banners:

-- Meanwhile Horsemen fever is growing; once mere entertainers, they're quickly becoming folk heroes -- And with their third, and reportedly final show coming up in three days, the question on everyone’s mind is- can they top themselves? REVERSE SHOWS DYLAN AND ALMA at the BAR IN THE TRUMP HOTE watching the television with mixed emotions. Alma clicks her phone:
The Horsemen are in the air.
Yeah.
On their way to LA.
Yeah.
Our flight leaves in three hours. Dylan finishes his drink- turns to Alma.
That leaves us with two hours. Alma hesitates, considering, then:
I know what it’s like, when things go bad in a marriage. When mine ended, well, let’s just say I was ho girl scout. I know this could be something more... (MORE)

{pauses) But I’ve spent the last five years of my life busting underage movie stars for doing coke and over the hill singers for doing underage girls, and all of them for driving under the influence afterwards. This is my first real case, and I won’t mess up because I’m being distracted by... personal matters. (meaningfully) Like you did. Alma leans close to Dylan, their lips almost touching. ALMA VARGAS (CONT’D) See you on the plane, Agent Hobbes. HOLD ON DYLAN’S FACE, as Alma walks away.
Talk about preparation...
QUICK IMAGES: FBI AGENTS milling around the space, dustin for fingerprints on the furniture, on the phones, while w hear AGENT FULLER ON THE SOUNDTRACK:

-- Some dummy company, Kaplan Inc., leased out office space in the Stonebridge Life building months before last night's show. They had access to the building; blueprints the entire space. They stole access cards, keys, you name it, and from internal phone records and security files, gained access to Stonebridge’s entire database as well... IMAGES OF AGENTS questioning a NUMBER OF YOUNG TEMPS, the we saw in the scene with “George Kaplan” among them: AGENT FULLER (V.0.) (CONT’D) -- They hired temps, never for more than three days at a time, none of whom ever saw anyone who worked at the company. (MORE)
On the night of the show, a Mr. George Kaplan finally put in an appearance, and apparently broke into Arthur Tressler's office, accessed his private computer and account...
Agent Fuller finishes filling in Dylan, SAC Hernandez and Thaddeus Bradley:
-- and the rest is history.

The money for the office rent came out of Stonebridge Life’s own coffers. These guys are real good, and they’re making us look real bad. (hard) Three days to their last show. We get caught with our pants down again, heads are gonna roll. Thaddeus Bradley is chuckling; the others turn to him:
What’s so goddamn funny?
“George Kaplan.”
What about him?
I made Michael Atlas in disguise, slipping into the theater at the last minute before the show. Clearly, he got past your eagle- eyes without much of an effort.
Atlas was with the others from the moment they left the hotel. Inspector Vargas saw him with her own eyes.  63.
She saw someone disguised as Michael Atlas, while Atlas himself was in New York City, disguised as “George Kaplan.” (smiles) He always did have an unhealthy fascination with Cary Grant.
Alright. Maybe there is a Fifth Horseman. Probably the same one who was in disguise as the others in Vegas, while they were in Paris, pulling off the bank job, but-
Five Horsemen, six Horsemen... How do we know there aren’t ten of them? How do we know they’re not a front for a whole bunch of guys-?
Unlikely. I wouldn’t waste precious time contemplating it.
What would you do, Bradley? I’m sick of you telling us what we don’t know, without giving us anything we can actually use -- For all we know you’re the Fifth Horseman.

Which is why you had me followed all day in Atlantic City. Were you my shadow, Agent Hobbes? Whoever it was, I must admit he was rather good, I couldn’t make head or tail of him... Dylan’s face is tight. He says nothing, biting down his embarrassment, as Thaddeus continues: THADDEUS (CONT’D) In any case, it’s your job to make the case stick. I’m here to tell you what I know , which at present is a hell of a lot more than you do. (turns to Agent Fuller) (MORE)

THADDEUS (CONT’D) -And to spare you the price of a discount DVD: the new phones were simply slipped into the audience’s bags and pockets when they passed through “security”; an illusionist might employ a dozen such sleight of hand artists and cutpurses at any given show.
I might be a rube, but even I kinda figured that. In fact this whole Tressler thing wasn’t all that much of a trick, you ask me.

It wasn’t meant to be. It’s called the “Mezzo”-a kind of entre-acte. Not particularly impressive on its own, but designed to get the audience on your side- which they certainly have succeeded in doing- while laying the groundwork for a final denouement.
What I don’t get is why they’re doing all this and not keeping any of the money.

The Four Horsemen’s methods might be mysterious, but their motives are not. They’re not after wealth. They’re after fame, immortality. To be mentioned in the same breath as Robert-Houdin, Hermann, Houdini. (pauses) But who would risk life in prison only to remain anonymous in success? This fifth Horseman- and there is a fifth, without a doubt- his motives are as mysterious as his methods.

You know what I don’t buy? Your motives. You told us you want to be relevant- but what you are is hated. You break the code of your own kind every day, and for what? A few bucks, fifteen minutes of fame? Don’t you have any sense of honor?  65.

Is there something you love, Agent Hobbes? That you would protect even at the expense of your own happiness or reputation? Dylan gives no answer. Thaddeus continues: THADDEUS (CONT’D) There is a legend- nothing we magic types love more than a good legend- of a secret sect of magicians that existed at the beginnings of our order’s inception. Perhaps as long ago as ancient Mesopotamia. This sect was known as “The Eye”- (smiles) -Where did you think the Masons got it from? “The Eye” was a cult within a cult; a secret society whose task it was to uphold the honor of the craft- something like your own Internal Affairs Department, yes? And when a rogue magician overstepped his bounds, or misused his craft, it was the task of The Eye to bring him down in a manner that would restore the honor of the order. Thaddeus’s voice is low, but his emotions are boiling: THADDEUS (CONT’D) Most of my “kind” as you put it, have devolved into a shameful lot of showboating Hollywood wannabes and Las Vegas whores. They have turned magic into vulgar pornography. Unfortunately, there is no secret order to protect my beloved art, so I have taken that onerous task upon my own shoulders.
For a six figure television deal.
Fire with fire, Agent Hobbes. Alma has entered the doorway, a sheaf of papers in her ha  66.

How about we protect our reputation as law enforcement officers, before these guys make us look like a bunch of rank amateurs again? (then) While you’ve been killing valuable time giving each other the macho stare-down, I found something you should see.
Alma is standing in front of several COMPUTERS, sheaves o paper scattered all around her, as the others look on:
I used the bureau’s codes to trace every account Tressler had stashed his ill gotten gains in... amazing, the access you guys have, by the way.
Yeah, thanks to Osama. We got in there after 9-11, and never left.
Why we vote Republican.
Right. In any case, among many other banks around the world, Arthur Tressler has a fairly significant account with Credit Lyonnais.
Among many other banks.
But he only has a secure safety deposit box in one.
Arthur Tressler has a safety deposit box in Paris? In the bank branch the Four Horsemen robbed?
I, of course, do not have the authority to have it searched. You, on the other hand...  67. Dylan smiles admiringly at Alma:
-Are about to turn the lights up on the Four Horsemen’s little party.
RODERIGO SANTAYANA is surrounded by silicon BLONDES, doin body shots. ALEX HERO is next to him, chatting up a prett girl; TITLE READS: Skybar - Los Angeles - California

Girl, I am not talking about hip hop. I’m talking about R&B- romance. I steal your heart, baby. Album cover is like, got one hand like this- (covers the girl’s breast with his hand) The other is holding the Ace of Hearts, you know, like that shit was your heart, and I stole it. Alex feels another body, turns to find himself facing an attractive BRITISH WOMAN; a CAMERAMAN with a small CAMERA behind her:
Alex- I’m Thelma Jones, from Sky News. Would you-
Sorry ma’am, this is a business- free zone, know what I mean? You want an interview, call-
Oh, come on, do you know what I had to do to get the bouncer to let us in here? Show us a little magic, won’t you, love? Alex holds his fingers to his head, squeezes his eyes shu
My powers tell me... you’re wearing red underwear with pink lace.  68.
I didn’t know you were a mentalist, too.
I’m not. He HOLDS UP the pair of RED PANTIES -- The British Woman’ eyes open wide; she checks under her dress, then gasps in disbelief, and:
That’1l be enough of that. London takes the underwear from Alex’s hand and gives it to the British Woman; turns back to Alex: LONDON (CONT’D) It’s time.
MICHAEL ATLAS is standing at the pay-phone, speaking as c whizz by on Sunset Boulevard:
Just give me the word, and we’re on. (listens; and) Alright. Fired up, ready to go.
Michael signs a few AUTOGRAPHS as he makes his way toward elevators; hands a KID an extra napkin and says-—

Hey, see that guy over there, at the bar? Can you give this to him? THE KID nods, hurries to a MAN sitting at the bar, sippin Martini, and hands him the napkin; the man unfolds it, se there’s a TWENTY DOLLAR BILL in there, and written on the napkin: HAVE ONE ON ME, Mr. G-MAN - NIGHTY NIGHT.
Michael steps inside, then stops in the foyer as he sees: LONDON OSBORNE, RODERIGO and ALEX HERO all are there wait for him.  69.
Let yourself in, why don’t you? (no answer) I detect an Ides of March vibe in here. Are you hiding daggers under your sleeves?
Who is he? Michael knew this was coming; he sighs, shaking his head:
We’ve been through this. I don’t know.

When I was a young apprentice touring with Reynaldino, he found out his daughter was slipping into my room. One morning in Las Carnes I went to the outhouse to do what you do in an outhouse. When I opened the door I found myself in Carboneras, two hundred kilometers away. Took me three years to figure out how he did that. I swore from that day on I would be the one pulling the strings. I don’t like this.

Don’t like what? Being the talk of the entire world? Famous beyond your wildest dreams? (real emotion seeping in) You know what I remember about my youth? TV dinners. Reruns. Volume turned up to drown out my parents’ squabble du jour. Trying to make myself be small, to disappear. To be nothing. That’s what I swore I’d never go back to. (pauses) No one will ever forget what we’re doing, as long as magic is talked about. The others watch Michael simmer down. They’ve never seen like this; then:  70. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) The Horsemen was his idea. He brought me in, and I came to you. He’s done everything he said he would, to aT. And his only stipulation was anonymity.
That’s a big bloody stipulation.
He was right there with you in Atlantic City, wearing my face. If you’re so concerned, you should have asked him yourself.
I did. He told me to sod off.
London tried to put the stare on him, too... guy laughed in his face. Some funny shit, homes.
Whoever this bloke is, he’s good. And plugged in as hell. Everything he told us to say to provoke those Feds was spot on. Got them hot to trot like greyhounds on a hare.
So what’s the problem?
It’s all been good so far, but we're about to get into the big money. How do we know he’s not setting us up to eat it this time.
We don’t.
Makes it bloody dangerous, mate.
Bloody dangerous. And bloody fun. (then) Are the Four Horsemen going out on a cute credit scam trick -- or are we going out on top of the world?  71. The others consider Michael’s words, then:
Top o’ the world, Ma.
IMAGES OF A SECURITY BOX- shot from every angle- appear i various sizes on a SERIES OF MONITORS; a forensic agent’s

Magnified images show the lock was jimmied. Hardly a scratch. Good work. They definitely got in there. Dylan, Alma Vargas, Agent Fuller, Thaddeus Bradley and a handful of FBI AGENTS are studying the images on the scre
And what the hell was in there? Alma reads from a printed out list:

A couple of diamond rings- the kind you give a girl you want to convince of your intentions. Ora couple of girls. A watch with his father’s inscription on it. A letter from an ex-wife. And that, as they say, is all she wrote.
They did not break into that box only to leave everything in it intact. There has to be something you’re missing.

You’re right about that. In fact, I had them go over the base of the box with one of those “scientific instruments we’re so proud of”- an infra-blue scanner. IMAGES OF THE BOTTOM OF THE BOX appear on the MONITOR; th is an IMPRINT VISIBLE -- LINES THAT LOOK LIKE A CORNER FR

head_text.subj: AN ARCHITECTURAL BLUEPRINT, AS WELL AS SEVERAL NUMBERS, C

text: DYLAN (CONT’D) Residue from blueprints of some kind. Printed on good old fashioned carbon paper. (to Thaddeus) See, around here, we do real magic.
Blueprints for what?
Impossible to tell, with the little we've got. What about the numbers? A YOUNG AGENT turns from the screen he is studying:
Last ID numbers of every Federal Building in California. Where’s their. .?
Their next show is in LA- tomorrow night. But that doesn’t mean much. They pulled off their robberies a good distance away from their shows both times, and-
Actually, the second location was a good deal closer than the first. Their preparation time for this one will be even less, and wherever they’re planning to...
The money factory.
The what?

The Federal Reserve Printing House, in Salinas. It’s about twenty miles East of Downtown LA. Last number before the code is cut off matches... He types a few keys, and all the screens show “THE MONEY FACTORY”- A SQUAT, INDUSTRIAL BUILDING situated in the mi of a humdrum neighborhood.  73.
How much money does a place like that print? The Young Agent types again, and:
Eight. Hundred. Million. Cash. Every day. No such facility has ever been compromised -- Ever. The agents fall silent. Then:
These guys got some balls on ‘em. EXT. ARTHUR TRESSLER’S MANSION - DAY There are several UNMARKED CARS in the driveway, the occu of the mansion being under house arrest; on the SOUNDTRAC
Tell us about the money factory. INT. LIVING ROOM - TRESSLER’S MANSION - CONTINUOUS Arthur Tressler is seated in front of a lavish fireplace, seething, as he faces Dylan and Alma Vargas:
I don’t know what you’re talking about.
We followed your money, found your account at the Credit Lyonnais in Paris. We also found your security deposit box there, and what was in it.
You went into my private box? There are laws that-
We didn’t go into it. The French did, under the blanket of financial terrorism laws too complicated for me to-
-So what? So you found my father’s watch...  74.
-And two rings.
There’s more than one pretty girl in Paris.
And the blueprints for the Money Factory.
I swear to Christ, I do not know what that is.

The Federal Reserve Printing House, in Salinas. We also traced payments to employees who work at that facility, cleverly funneled so as not to compromise their identities. (then) Were you siphoning freshly printed money from the US government, Mr. Tressler?
I was not. I am being set up by those four goddamn magicians, you morons.
Maybe, maybe not. If you’1ll excuse me for saying so, you’re a hard man to trust, Mr. Tressler.

There is, however, one thing we do know with certainty -- The only way to breach a facility like that is with someone on the inside. We want the names of the employees you sent money to, and we want them now.
I told you, I have no idea what you’re talking about. The Horsemen were able to access my account -- they could be paying whoever they want to with my money. (hard) (MORE)
You want to find these guys, you’re gonna have to do it yourselves.

MUSIC BLASTS through the windows -- MOTORCYCLES are parke a row in front; this is as openly bad-ass a bar as can be imagined, and LONDON OSBORNE steps into FRAME: walking toward the bar, listening to the voice in his ear-piece:
You find it?
Yeah, I bloody found it, mate. Someday, when I found out who you are, I’1ll return the favor. Cheers.

London walks into the raucous space; he’s wearing glasses hat, nothing major, just enough to keep him from being ea recognizable. He pushes his way to the bar, jostling a BI BRUISER and leans toward the BARTENDER, who’s shoulder we over:
I’1l have a Guinness.
Don’t have Guinness.
Then how about a bloody mojito? Not too leafy. The Bartender steps out of frame, and London takes in his surroundings, until the Bartender slams some kind of DRIN down in front of him.
Mojitos are eight bucks. Ten for you.
Make it twenty, for all I care. This bloke here with the rancid breath is paying for it, innat right? THE BIG BRUISER can hardly believe his ears:  76.
I’m buyin’ a plot for your grave, asshole.
And I thought the English had bad teeth. Tell you what, why don’t you give him thirty and we’1l call it a day.
I am about to end your life.

No you’re not. You’re weak. You’re weak as a baby. You’re so bloody weak I can bring you to your knees with my little finger- London reaches out, presses the Big Bruiser’s shoulder wi finger, and to the shock of everyone around the bar, the slowly sinks down to his knees. London looks around, smiles: LONDON (CONT’D) Next round is on me.

CAMERA BOOMS down the white deco exterior, as we hear an AGENT’S VOICE ON THE SOUNDTRACK: AGENT’S VOICE (V.0.) We lost Osborne somewhere on the East Side. Guy is a really tough follow. STOP ON A CAR sitting across the street from the hotel; AGENT FULLER, eating a ham sandwich, within:
Roger that. The others are still in the hotel- least we didn’t make any of ‘em leaving -- isn’t that right? PAN OVER to THADDEUS BRADLEY, sitting beside Fuller, look very put out:
Not that I’ve noticed.  77.
Keep your eyes peeled, in case one of ‘em tries something funny. The rest of us might miss it -- being such a big bunch of rubes and all.

I’1l do my best- That is, if I can make anything out through the haze of onion wafting from that thing you’re shoving into your maw. Crack open a window, will you? Agent Fuller glares at Thaddeus, then reaches for the win release... as the window goes down we see, at the crosswa A HOMELESS MAN in a HOODIE trying to wipe the windshields irate driver’s windows, moving further and further away w each consecutive car, and we
As a smile of recognition spreads across his face.

Dylan and Alma step out of an unmarked car. They take in area: the security cameras hidden in the street-lights, t guards perched at the top of the building; TITLE CARD REA Bureau of Engraving and Printing - City of Salinas
Damn. I could leave my wallet on the ground, catch a movie, and nobody would steal it. Not on this block. Dylan shoots Alma a look and heads for the doors; we hear the SOUNDTRACK:
-- You think these hocus pocus guys are going to try to rob this facility..?
Dylan and Alma stand across from LT. THOMAS and OFFICER SIEGEL.  78.
-- Next thing Siegfried and Roy are gonna knock over the US Mint.
Hadn’t heard about that, but thanks for the tip.
Let me give you a little history lesson. The BEP has been around since 1861, and in that time, in all our facilities, do you know how many successful robberies there’ve been? Zero. Not one.
We’re not some we’re not some ragtag rent-a-cops. We are the BEP police force. No one’s getting in here.
There have been attempts before, sure. But they’ve always been inside jobs, and they’ve always been caught.

I didn’t say it wasn’t going to be an inside job -- in part. (then) We have indications that they have blueprints to this facility. They know the exact location of every nail and screw drilled into this place, and-
And it won’t make a difference.
Show me why not.
Alma and Dylan are at the X-RAY MACHINES. They dump their money and change into bins, as Officer Siegel and Lt. Tho watch on.  79.

No money enters the Money Factory, or leaves the Money Factory. Except the money we print. They step into the bustling space. HEAVY MACHINERY HUMS a around. A WORKER pushes a large pallet of glass-encased BILLS across the floor.
How much cash just rolled by? Lt. Thomas shrugs, used to this:

A lot. WORKERS swipe their cards to move from one area of the ga area to another. ARMED GUARDS watch the floor from a catw high above them. LT. THOMAS (CONT’D) These men are the best in the business. Everyone in this room has SSBI, SCI and SAP level security clearance. They could care less about money.
Except for the ones receiving anonymous payments from the man who had somehow gained possession of the blueprints to this facility.
Want to tell me who they are?
Sure I want to. We just don’t know.

Yeah. Be sure to let us know when you find out. They stop in front of a CAGED IN HOLDING AREA where the PALLET OF BILLS has been wheeled into; the gate shut behi it.  80. LT. THOMAS (CONT’D) The new printed money stays here. It’s collected by armored truck in the morning, and delivered to banks all over the Southland.
And there’s how many dollars in here on a given night?
Eight hundred and fifty million. Dylan and Alma share an awed look; and
The BEP cops show Dylan and Alma the small space, surroun by MONITORS:
Let’s assume our boys are going to hit this place. Tonight. If you were them, knowing what you know about this facility, how would you get in?

I wouldn’t. There are cameras in every corner of the building. Every employee uses a scan card to move from one section to another. Anyone goes where they don’t belong, the gates come down. We got our guy. We got our money.
Except for you.
What?
You just opened three doors in a row to allow us in here; clearly you have a master pass that allows you access to the entire building.
(countenance darkening) What are you saying?  sl.
Just that if someone wanted to rob this place... it would help if they knew you.
Except for one thing, detective. Everyone would know it was me. (hard) I spend enough time behind bars during the day. I don’t have any desire to spend my nights the same way.
Everyone here’s given the strictest background check. You’re free to run another, anytime.
Time’s the one thing we don’t have.

You got the jump on these guys. You know they’re gonna try and hit this place, and they don’t know you know it. You’re so worried, cordon us off, no one gets in, no one gets out. (smiles) Show never happens.
Dylan and Alma sit side by side, silent. Then:
He’s right.
Yeah. Cordon it off. Like the Green Zone in Baghdad. No robbery...
No arrest. (beat) Fuck that.
THE “HOMELESS MAN” is shuffling down a side-street; WE RA FOCUS to reveal that we are looking at him from  82. INSIDE THE UNMARKED CAR which AGENT FULLER driving, THADD beside him:

Keep on him. It’s the boy, Alex Hero. No doubt about it. ZOOM IN TO THE “HOMELESS MAN”- and we see there is an EAR PIECE hidden under his hair. His lips are moving. BACK TO AGENT FULLER: who speaks to the CAR-PHONE:
You guys have him on audio?
SEVERAL AGENTS occupy the van, driving on a parallel stre listening to high-sensitivity audio devices:
Yeah, we got him. He’s on right now.
-- Yo, I’ve been made. I’m sure of it. They’re on me. I'm aborting.

No way. We're committed and we're on the clock. Lose them. Whatever it takes. INT. AGENT FULLER’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Through the window Agent Fuller sees “Homeless Man” make sudden turn into a ONE WAY ALLEY, hurrying in the other direction, and:

Damn. He spins the wheel, and tears up the street in order to c up with the “Homeless Man” at the other end of the block; Thaddeus holds on tightly, as they round the corner and s The “Homeless Man” opening the door of a PARKED AUDI; he slips into the vehicle -- We can see his hands reach unde the dash, and the ENGINE HUMS TO LIFE.  83. AGENT FULLER (CONT’D) I don’t believe it. This little bastard is gonna make me chase his ass. This is gonna get- VOOM! “HOMELESS MAN” tears out of the parking spot and ro right past the Agent Fuller’s car, racing in the opposite direction; and AGENT FULLER makes a hard U-Turn, burning rubber, and giv chase; Thaddeus shouts:
Let me out. I didn’t sign up for this.
You want credit for breaking the case, you gotta be there when it gets broke! (grins) Maybe you’ll get a new TV show. AND THEY TEAR DOWN THE STREET AFTER THE AUDI, as:
The sweating “Homeless Man” shouts into his ear-piece:
They’re on my ass, yo. This is not what I do, do you hear me? This is not what I do.
The AGENT driving does his best to keep up on the paralle street, as they hear from their equipment:
If they can see you, they can hear you. No more communication. You’re on your own.
Hey..! But the line’s gone dead; nothing but static, and:  84.
